abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Women in Development
            Project for Gambia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also highly satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the formulation of a national gender
            policy to provide strategic direction for future efforts was
            timely and appropriate. However, the policy would need to be
            periodically reviewed and aligned, monitored and evaluated,
            so as to retain its relevance and usefulness. The
            women's bureau has undoubtedly a lead role in this
            process and will required support and partnership to
            achieved desired results. The bureau's role cannot be
            under emphasized in a gender oriented project and it is only
            a capacitized bureau which could discharge the expected
            functions adequately. The program content of future project
            designs should also be so balanced to ensure that other
            critical areas of concern to women are accordingly
            incorporated. The non implementation of the activities
            envisaged under the post-harvest technology sector had
            affected the impact of the project on the lives of the
            beneficiary women. Women in the project areas as well as
            those outside of the project areas consistently lamented or
            help in this sector. There is an urgent need for
            intervention in the area of post-harvest technology
            sub-sector, of course through a gender perspective.
